courses.title: Installation and Setup
courses.description: This course guides you through the essential setup steps and introduces the core concepts
courses.review: Great course! Clear explanations and practical examples. Helped me understand how Signals differ from RxJS.

courses.title: Traditional Components
courses.description: Discover how traditional Angular components shape your application's user interface.
courses.review: Solid breakdown of component architecture. Loved the examples and visual explanations.

courses.title: Standalone Components
courses.description: Learn how standalone components simplify Angular development by removing the need for NgModules.
courses.review: Helped me understand when to use standalone components and how they simplify module management.

courses.title: Binding
courses.description: Dive into data binding in Angular and learn how it connects your application's logic to the user interface.
courses.review: Covers all types of binding clearlyâ€”property, event, and two-way.

courses.title: Dependency Injection
courses.description: Explore how Angularâ€™s dependency injection system simplifies code management and promotes modular design.
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: DI is powerful once you understand providers and injectors.

courses.title: Observables
courses.description: You'll learn how Observables work under the hood, how to create and subscribe to them, and how they integrate with Angular services and HTTP requests.
courses.review: This course provides a solid foundation in using Observables within Angular. The explanations are clear, and the examples are practical, especially the sections on HTTP requests and reactive forms.

courses.title: Interface
courses.description: Understand how interfaces in Angular help define the shape of data and enforce type safety. .
courses.review: Interfaces help enforce structure and improve type safety.
courses.codeSnippet: interface Course { title: string; duration: string; }

courses.title: Routing and Navigation
courses.description: Master Angularâ€™s routing and navigation system to build seamless, single-page applications..
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Routing was tricky at first, but guards and lazy loading made it click.

courses.title: Reactive Forms
courses.description: Gain a deep understanding of reactive forms in Angular and how they enable dynamic, scalable form handling.
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Reactive forms are powerful for validation and dynamic controls.
courses.codeSnippet: this.form = new FormGroup({ name: new FormControl('') });

courses.title: RxJS Operators
courses.description: Unlock the power of RxJS operators to transform, filter, and manage streams of data in Angular.
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: RxJS is a beast, but once you get map, mergeMap, and switchMap, itâ€™s ðŸ”¥.

courses.title: Testing & Debugging
courses.description: Learn how to write effective tests and debug Angular applications with confidence. .
courses.difficulty: Hard, ðŸ”¥ Coffeeâ€™s Cold & Youâ€™re Debugging
courses.review: Unit testing with Jasmine and Karma was easier than expected. Debugging tips were gold.

courses.title: Extras
courses.description: Explore additional Angular features including working with images, creating and using pipes, and handling advanced syntax.
courses.review: A fun wrap-up of random but useful Angular tricks.

steps: A new user story, bug, or feature is created in Azure Boards.
Work items are documented with a title, description, and acceptance criteria.
Work item is reviewed during backlog refinement.
Effort is estimated using story points or time.
Acceptance criteria and requirements are confirmed.
Item is prioritized and marked 'Ready for Dev'.
Pull the latest updates from the main branch.
Go to Azure Repos and create a new branch.
Use 'feature/' for new functionality or 'bug/' for fixes. Name the branch as: [user-story-id]-[three-word-description] (e.g., 1234-update-user-profile).
Fetch the new branch in VS Code. Begin development work in your local environment.
Use QA link to simulate staging or test with QA-specific data.
Use Sales Agreement Numbers from QA or query the database.
Preview changes in local environment using the correct sales agreement.
Run unit tests in the .spec.ts files (Angular project).
Definition of Done (DoD): Ensure the story meets all acceptance criteria, tests pass, and documentation is updated.
Ensure all tests pass before committing.
Commit your changes.
Push the branch to Azure Repos.
Create a PR with title: WI [user story number] | [Title of user story].
Add a description using bullet points:
- What was changed
- Any special considerations
- Testing steps or notes
CI Triggered Automatically
When a PR is created or updated, the CI pipeline runs:
- Builds the code
- Runs automated tests (unit, integration, etc.)
- Checks code quality (linters, formatters)
Peer Review
Developers pull the branch locally, test, and review the code.
If the CI pipeline fails, the PR is blocked until issues are resolved.
Once the code passes CI and is approved by reviewers, it can be merged.
PR has been approved and merged into the main or staging branch.
QA environment is updated with the latest changes.
Test cases are reviewed and confirmed with the QA team.
QA engineers validate the story against acceptance criteria.
Regression testing is performed on affected areas.
Bugs or issues are logged in Azure Boards and assigned to devs.
Item is either passed or sent back to 'In Dev Progress' for fixes.
Work item has passed QA testing and meets Definition of Done.
Feature is included in production release or release candidate.
Documentation and changelogs are updated.
Item is closed in Azure Boards.
